against solid waste being blown or hurled from such vehicles the vehicles shall be operated in such a manner as not to create a nuisance or safety hazard or otherwise adversely affect public health the solid waste hauled in such vehicles shall not be spilled dumped or thrown onto any public property highway or rightofway or upon any private premises other than an approved site for a solid waste management facility in the event any solid waste is spilled dumped or thrown off a vehicle transporting same the operator of the vehicle shall be responsible for immediately retrieving and removing such waste all such vehicles and solid waste storage containers shall be stored in a neat and sanitary condition free from obnoxious odor and insect infestation 6 hours of operation the operation of solid waste management facilities located adjacent to any area zoned or used for residential development shall be restricted to between  am and  pm where deemed necessary the city council may impose additional restrictions on hours of operation for any solid waste management facility as a stipulation to the conditional use permit 7 screening a solid waste management facilities shall be adequately screened or buffered within required setbacks from all adjacent properties and public streets and rightsofway buffering shall at a minimum meet the landscape requirements set forth in the city zoning ordinance in the case of sanitary and debris landfills a 50foot natural buffer consisting of existing mature trees shall be preserved to screen the landfill from adjacent properties zoned or used for residential purposes the location and adequacy of such natural buffers shall be determined by city council in the issuance of a conditional use permit or by the director of development and permits or designee for lawfully existing landfills where natural buffers do not exist or are deemed insufficient to protect adjacent residential properties the landfill shall be screened from such properties with a 50foot buffer along property lines said buffer to be vegetated with no less than nine large trees as defined in the chesapeake landscape specification manual and 75 shrubs per 100 linear feet of buffer area such trees and shrubs shall be placed throughout the width of the buffer in a manner approved by the city council in the issuance of use permits or by the director of development and permits or designee for lawfully existing landfills in cases where it is not physically possible to locate a newly established 50foot buffer along property lines a planting plan showing alternative locations for the buffer shall be submitted to city council for final determination all required buffers whether consisting of existing vegetation newly planted vegetation or combination approved by the city council or the director of development and permit or designee as the case may be shall be preserved and maintained by the owner or operator of the landfill  provided that however the owner or operator shall not be held responsible for replacement of any portion of a buffer destroyed due to acquisition of land within the buffer by an entity having the power of eminent domain b in addition to the requirements in subsection a above city council may impose further buffering requirements whether consisting of existing natural or vegetation or newly planted vegetation as a condition of the use permit or at any time during the operation of a solid waste management facility where city council finds that additional screening is necessary to protect surrounding properties from identified adverse impacts generated by the facility or the operation thereof such enhanced buffering shall not exceed a width of 50 feet which shall be in addition to the buffer requirements set out in subsection a above the additional buffer area shall be placed in locations deemed appropriate by city council and shall contain vegetation either preserved newly planted or both consisting of nine large trees as defined in the chesapeake landscape specification manual and 75 shrubs per 100 linear feet of buffer area the required vegetation shall be located throughout the width of the buffer in a manner approved by city council and may upon the direction of city council be supplemented by a threefoot berm or sixfoot fence such additional landscaping shall be preserved and maintained by the owner or operator of the solid waste management facility  provided that however the owner or operator shall not be held responsible for the replacement of any portion of a buffer destroyed due to the acquisition of land within the buffer by an entity having the power of eminent domain 8 fencing where deemed necessary to protect surrounding properties from identified adverse impacts city council may as a condition of the use permit or at any time during the operation of a solid waste management facility require the applicant or operator to erect fencing on the solid waste management facility site at such locations determined to be necessary to protect adjacent properties and surrounding communities unless otherwise directed by city council such fence shall be erected to a height of six feet shall consist of chain link anchor or stockade type materials and shall completely encircle the solid waste management facility the fence shall remain for so long as solid waste is processed or stored upon the property and shall be maintained in good repair all gates and other entrances to the site shall be kept closed and locked when not in use for ingress and egress purposes 9 lining solid beyond the footprint of disposal areas existing on the effective date of o005  10 sloping and height the slope of all banks of debris or sanitary landfills shall not exceed three feet horizontal to 140 feet above mean sea level in the case of a lawfully existing solid waste management facility these sloping and height restrictions shall only apply to physical expansions beyond the footprint of disposal areas existing on the effective date of o005  11 solid waste below original ground level no solid waste other than inert and organic waste shall be stored or disposed of below original ground waste management facility these restrictions shall only apply to physical expansions beyond the footprint of disposal areas existing on the effective date of o005  12 contamination of groundwater lakes rivers streams and other waterways no solid waste management facility shall be constructed or operated in such a manner that it contaminates or pollutes groundwater lakes rivers streams or other waterways to this end all owners and operators of sanitary and debris landfills shall comply with the groundwater monitoring requirements imposed on new sanitary and debris landfills by the virginia department of environmental quality deq as set out in the virginia solid waste management regulations the owner or operator of a sanitary or debris landfill shall provide the director with copies of all groundwater monitoring programs tests records sampling analytical reports notices of noncompliance notices of violation permits and other similar documents submitted to or received from the deq pertaining to water quality all such documents shall be provided to the director in a timely manner not to exceed ten days from the date of receipt or delivery in the event the director learns or is made aware that an owner or operator of a sanitary or debris landfill has failed to strictly comply with deq laws and regulations governing groundwater monitoring and water quality standards or has received a variance therefrom or that groundwater analyses indicate contaminant levels beyond the maximum levels set out in the federal safe water drinking act or the virginia solid waste management regulations the director may require additional testing and analysis where on the basis of either deq water quality records or the citys independently required water quality tests it is conclusive that the operation of the landfill is causing water quality degradation in violation of federal or state standards the director shall issue a notice of violation requiring immediate correction of the violation the thorough cessation of all activities directly contributing to the contamination and the submittal of a corrective action plan detailing the nature and timing of all remedial steps that will be taken to provide alternate water supplies to affected residents and to restore water quality to its condition prior to the identified contamination the corrective action plan shall be submitted to the director for approval in exigent circumstances the director may order the cessation of all landfill operations and expansions as necessary to avoid significant adverse impact on the public health and environment where a cease and desist notice is issued all further operations and expansions will be prohibited until such time that the director determines on the basis of reliable testing analysis and reporting that the landfill activities directly contributing to nonconformance with the federal safe drinking water act or the virginia solid waste management regulations have ceased  that a corrective action plan as described above has been submitted to and approved by the director  and that the owner or operator of the landfill has shown due diligence in taking initial steps to implement the corrective action plan the director may issue or reissue a notice to cease and desist landfill operations or expansions if at any time the owner or operator fails to comply with the directives of a notice of violation or fails to exercise due diligence in the implementation of an approved corrective action plan in interpreting and applying this subsection the city shall not be bound by any variances exceptions or suspensions granted by the deq with regard to groundwater monitoring or water quality and may continue to require testing and corrective action where it is evident that the operation of the landfill is causing water quality degradation in violation of the standards set forth in the federal safe drinking water act and the virginia solid waste management regulations 13 damaged well restoration any person owning or operating a solid waste management facility in a manner that adversely affects a well or diminution of groundwater shall provide the well owner with a replacement water supply and water supply system equal in quality to the water supply and water supply system damaged by the solid waste management facility contamination shall be determined on the basis of the standards adopted by the deq under the virginia solid waste management regulations and imposed under the federal safe drinking water act where the groundwater monitoring requirements and water quality standards referenced in subsection 12 above indicate contamination under these state and federal regulations and laws the director may order the owner or operator of the sanitary or debris landfill to perform water quality sampling and analysis on wells within the plume of contamination as determined in accordance with standards set out in the virginia solid waste management regulations such sampling and analysis shall be required only to the extent necessary to test for the identified contaminants shown to exceed acceptable levels under the virginia solid waste management regulations or the federal safe drinking water act in the event such sampling and analysis indicates degradation of a wells water supply under these standards the director shall order the immediate replacement of the water supply in accordance with this section the director may also require testing to determine whether a water supply has been subject to diminution upon specific complaint of a well owner having a reasonable basis in fact if such testing shows the complaint to be valid the owner or operator of the solid waste management facility shall be required to replace the water supply immediately 14 noise where the director determines that the owner or operator of any solid waste management facility is in repeated violation of the citys noise ordinance chapter 26 constitute a substantial threat to the public health or welfare the director may order the temporary cessation of solid waste management activities until such time that all reasonably available means as determined by the director have been taken to alleviate the noise such measures may include without limitation buffering designed to reduce sound transmission 15 hazardous radioactive nuclear waste solid waste management operations and any proposed expansion of the facility cease immediately  provided that the director may exercise reasonable discretion in allowing the inadvertent deposit of solid waste generators and companies that manage solid waste or recycle materials to make annual reports virginia  152939 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning solid waste means any garbage refuse sludge and other discarded material including solid liquid semisolid or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial residential commercial mining and agricultural operations or community activities but does not include the following 1 solid or dissolved material from domestic sewage  2 solid or dissolved material in irrigation return flows or in industrial discharges which are sources subject to a permit from the state water control board  or 3 source special nuclear or byproduct material as defined by the federal atomic energy act of 195 as amended solid waste management region means the cities of chesapeake norfolk portsmouth suffolk and virginia beach and the counties of franklin isle of wight and southampton solid waste recycling company means any nonresidential generator of solid waste and any company business or association or other party which collects transports processes or recycles solid waste to recycle means to 1 sell donate or otherwise transfer solid waste material to any other person located outside of the service area so that such waste material may be processed and used again as a raw material for a product which may or may not be similar to the original product 2 process a given waste material at a location within the service area so that such material may be used again as a raw material for a product which may or may not be similar to the original product    cross of the virginia 195 as amended vacation of public rightofway also referred to herein as street closure may be initiated upon motion of city council or upon application of any person in either case the request for vacation of rightofway shall be referred to the department of planning for processing in accordance with state law and the provisions set out below b all street closure proceedings initiated by application of any person shall be commenced by filing a petition with the department of planning on forms provided for this purpose the application shall include 1 the name and address of all applicants and all owners of property abutting the rightofway to be vacated 2 statements of consent to the street closure application signed by all owners of property abutting the subject rightofway who are not participating in the proceedings as applicants 3 a written description of the area to be vacated 4 a vicinity map and street closure exhibit depicting the precise location and dimensions of the area to be vacated the exhibit shall meet the minimum standards promulgated by the state library board for plats as interpreted and applied by the director of development and permits or designee the exhibit shall depict all parcels of land abutting the subject rightofway and all public and private easements public utility facilities and private franchise facilities located in or upon said rightofway the director of development and permits or designee may elect to waive the requirement for a street closure agreement in cases where the director determines that preparation of the exhibit will be cost prohibitive to the applicant 5 a title certification indicating fee simple ownership of the rightofway to be vacated where the city is not the fee simple owner the title certification must indicate the citys interest in the rightofway 6 a street closure agreement signed by all applicants promising to purchase the vacated rightofway at the price set or approved by city council 7 a filing fee in the amount of $10000 and a statement signed by all applicants indicating assumption of responsibility for all public advertising and notification costs associated with the processing of the street closure application c in cases where the street closure is initiated by motion of city council the department of planning shall provide a vicinity map identifying adjacent property owners the director of public works or designee shall prepare the street closure exhibit and conduct necessary research to determine the citys apparent interest in the rightofway d upon the filing of a complete application as determined by the director of planning the petition shall be reviewed by affected city departments as follows 1 review for consistency with the comprehensive plan by the department of planning 2 review for impact on the citys system of streets and highways by the director of development and permits or designee 3 review for impact on public safety and convenience by the director of public works or designee 4 review for impact on drainage by the director of public works or designee 5 review for impact on public utility facilities by the department of public utilities 6 review of the street closure exhibit by the director of development and permits or designee to verify completeness and conformity with the state library board standards 7 review by the citys rightofway agent or other employee having similar skills and duties designated by the city manager to estimate the price of the vacated rightofway to be paid by abutting landowners the price shall not exceed the fair market value of the vacated rightofway or its contributory value to abutting parcels whichever is greater the citys rightofway agent may to the extent deemed necessary utilize city assessments and private appraisals in estimating the price should private appraisals be utilized the cost of such appraisals shall be assessed to the applicant e upon completion of review the planning department shall schedule a public hearing for consideration of the street closure application by the city planning commission notice of the public hearing shall be published twice with at least six days elapsing between the first and second publication in a newspaper having general circulation in the city the notice shall specify the time and place of the public hearing at which persons may appear and be heard the cost of publishing the notice shall be assessed to the applicant f the planning commission shall hear the application and make recommendations to city council as to whether the street closure request should be approved approved with conditions or denied in making its recommendations the planning commission shall at a minimum consider the following factors 1 whether the vacation of the rightofway is consistent with the comprehensive plan in accordance with section 1522232 of the virginia 195 as amended 2 whether the vacation of the rightofway will adversely affect public safety or convenience or otherwise have negative impact on the citys system of streets and highways 3 whether the vacation of rightofway will adversely affect public or private utility facilities 4 whether the vacation of the rightofway will promote a public purpose including but not limited to improving traffic conditions disposing of surplus public land that is no longer functional or necessary alleviating undue public maintenance responsibilities promoting economic development and increasing real estate tax revenues 5 whether all properties abutting or in the immediate vicinity of the vacated rightofway will be left with reasonable access 6 whether any person affected by the street closure voices meritorious objections to same g following the planning commissions advisory action the street closure application shall be scheduled for a public hearing before city council the public hearing shall be advertised as set out in subsection e above with costs assessed to the applicant the planning commission and city council hearings may be concurrently advertised upon consent of the city council h in acting upon the street closure application city council may consider the criteria listed in subsection f above along with other relevant factors city council may impose conditions on any approval as deemed necessary to ensure that the street closure is in the best interest of the city and will promote public health safety welfare or convenience to the extent required by state law approval of the application shall require a threefourths vote of the members of city council 1    o094 10901  o100 81109 sale of public streets alleys easements and other public ways as a condition of the vacation of any public street alley easement or public rightofway a as permitted by section 668 of this chapter the director of development and permits or designee is authorized to issue permits for privately owned entryway structures and ornamental features other than signs in the public rightofway provided each of the following criteria are met 1 the applicant presents plans and elevations showing the proposed location size dimensions design architectural treatment and materials of the entryway structure or ornamental feature all such plans and elevations shall be subject to approval based solely on the reasonable discretion of the director of development and permits or designee in exercising this discretion the director of development and permits or designee should give due consideration to quality of materials and aesthetics and may seek recommendations of the director of planning in this regard 2 the applicant presents evidence of the owners financial ability to construct maintain and repair the entryway structure or ornamental feature for so long as such structure or feature is to remain on the property 3 the owner posts a cash bond or other acceptable surety with the director of development and permits or designee in an amount deemed sufficient to remove and dispose of the entryway structure or ornamental feature in the event it remains in the rightofway longer than permitted 4 the owner executes an agreement to promptly relocate or remove the entryway structure or ornamental feature when requested to do so by the city and to indemnify the city from all damages and losses suffered by any person or entity arising out of or alleged to have arisen out of the design construction placement maintenance failure to maintain repair relocation or removal of the structure or feature  or arising out of or alleged to have arisen out of the maintenance or failure to maintain the rightofway in the general vicinity of the structure or feature 5 the owner maintains the grass and other vegetation in the public rightofway in the general vicinity of the entryway structure or ornamental feature 6 the entryway structure or ornamental feature does not encroach on any governmental or public service company easements or utility facilities without written permission from the owner of the easement 7 the department of development and permits or designee determines that the entryway structure or ornamental feature will not impede traffic  hinder visibility  interfere with the maintenance or improvement of the rightofway or any public utility facility  or otherwise adversely affect adjacent properties or the public health safety or welfare any permit issued by the director of development and permits or designee under this section may be revoked at any time with or without cause upon 60 days notice to the owner of the entryway structure or ornamental feature b where any entryway structure ornamental feature sign or other building structure or device is unlawfully placed in the rightofway the director of public works or designee or director of development and permits or designee may remove same and either place the item on the private property immediately abutting the rightofway or take the item into custody if the item is taken into custody with the exception of illegal signs of any type due care shall be taken to determine ownership and send notice by first class mail to the owners last known address advising that the item may be reclaimed within a specified time period and upon reimbursement of all costs incurred by the city in the removal and storage of the item if ownership cannot be ascertained or if the owner fails to claim the item within the notice period or pay costs incurred by the city the item may be disposed of in addition the director of public works may immediately remove and dispose of any building structure sign or other device whether lawfully permitted or not that the director determines is in a state of disrepair or deteriorated to such a degree as to constitute a public safety hazard in the case of illegal signs of any type the notice provisions herein shall not apply in addition a citizen who has attended training provided by the director of public works and been designated by the director of public works as an approved member of the citys sign sweeper program may be authorized to remove temporary and snipe signs that do not comply with the requirements of the chesapeake zoning c as used herein the term entryway structure shall mean guardhouses and similar roofed structures intended to enhance or embellish a primary entrance to a residential subdivision shopping center commercial center industrial park or other unified development the term ornamental feature shall mean decorative devices including monuments statutes gardens walls trellises benches and similar devices neither term shall be interpreted to include signs as defined in section 14700 of the zoning ordinance o034 4803  o159 111604 state law reference subdivision and development virginia  15222401522276 article i  in general definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning alley means a minor public street primarily designed to serve as access to the side or rear of those properties whose principal frontage is on some other street building setback line means a line parallel to the front property lines in front of which no structure may be located chesapeake bay preservation area overlay district means the area so designated by the zoning ordinance of the city collector streets means streets which carry traffic from minor streets to the system of major streets construction plan means the component of a final subdivision plan required by subsections 7022d and 7026a and any other preliminary and final subdivision plan or final subdivision plat that includes an improvement of or modification to an existing or proposed public facility culdesac means a short street designed to have one end permanently closed with the closed end terminating by a vehicular turnaround dedication means the transfer of property to the city or other governmental entities for public purposes where a subdivision plat explicitly or implicitly designates certain areas as being dedicated to the city recordation of such plat shall in no way affect acceptance of such areas by the city for purposes of maintenance development means a tract of land developed or to be developed as a unit under single ownership or unified control which is to be used for any business industrial or other nonresidential purpose or is to contain three or more residential dwelling units the term development shall not be construed to include any property which will be principally devoted to agricultural production or conservation or to property owned by the city to be improved for recreational uses easement means a grant by a property owner of the use of land for a specific purpose or purposes major streets means streets and highways which are used primarily for traffic movement minor streets means streets which are used primarily for access to abutting property and not intended to provide for movement municipal means of or relating to the city of chesapeake or any of its agencies authorities boards or commissions including without limitation the chesapeake school board paper street means a street which by recorded plat or deed has been dedicated to the city but which has not been accepted by the city for maintenance purposes public facility means any improvement facility or service together with customary improvements and appurtenances thereto necessary to provide for public needs including without limitation streets alleys or pedestrian walks or paths  storm sewers  flood control improvements  water supply and distribution facilities  sanitary sewage disposal and treatment facilities  public utility energy and telephone services public street means an existing street or platted street dedicated for the use of the general public graded and paved or to be graded and paved in order that every person has the right to pass and to use it at all times for all purposes of travel transportation or parking to which it is adopted and devoted reservation means the withholding of designated areas from all permanent structures for the express purpose of allowing acquisition of such areas by the city or other governmental entities for public purposes when such acquisition is deemed necessary residual means any lot parcel or tract of land consisting of more than 15 acres which is designated on a subdivision plan or plat as remaining acreage not intended for development at the time of the subdivision there shall be no more than one residual parcel designated on a subdivision plat service drive means a public street generally paralleling and contiguous to a main travelled way primarily designed to promote safety by eliminating promiscuous ingress and egress to the rightofway or main highway and providing safe and orderly points of access at fairly uniformly spaced intervals site plan means a plan for development or a subdivision including all covenants grants or easements and other conditions relating to use location and bulk of buildings density of development common open space public facilities and such other information as required by the subdivision ordinance or zoning ordinance to which the proposed development or subdivision is subject street width means the shortest distance between the lines which delineate the rightofway of a street streets means strips of land subject to vehicular or pedestrian traffic and providing direct or indirect means of access to property including but not limited to road lane drive trail court place terrace alley avenue highway boulevard or any other thoroughfare stub street means a street that ends at the property line of a subdivision and is intended to continue on into the adjacent property when that property is developed subdivision means the division of any lot parcel or tract of land into two or more lots parcels tracts or other divisions of property for the immediate or future transfer of ownership or development including without limitation all changes in existing streets or lot lines all divisions which result in the creation of a new lot all divisions which are necessary to facilitate the development of a property for any purpose and all divisions of land which include a new street or the extension of an existing street the following divisions of land shall be exempt from the public improvement requirements set out in articles ii of this chapter  provided that no such property other than vacation of lot lines shall be deemed lawfully subdivided unless a plat as described in subsection 7022 and approved by the director of planning or other designated official has been properly recorded in the clerks office for the circuit court of the city as required by the virginia 1 agricultural division the division of property located wholly within an agricultural zoning district for bona fide agricultural use and not for development purposes provided that a the original tract of land is divided into parcels consisting of no less than 15 acres each including the residual of the original tract  b no new or extended public streets or other public facilities are required to serve the parcels as divided  c the plat depicting the division contains a note stating that the property is to be used for bona fide agricultural purposes only  d all parcels created by the division conform with applicable minimum development criteria set out in the citys zoning ordinance  and e no portion of the original tract of land is further subdivided for a period of one year from date of recordation of the plat depicting the agricultural division of land unless such property has been appropriately rezoned for development 2 resubdivision the minor adjustment or vacation of property lines which reallocates or consolidates land area of contiguous lots or parcels provided that the adjustment or vacation of property lines does not a result in the creation of any additional lots or parcels of land  b result in any increase in density or increased impact on public infrastructure  c involve or give rise to the need for the dedication construction or extension of a public street  or d create a nonconformity or increase or aggravate any existing nonconformity as to minimum development and use criteria set out in the citys zoning ordinance each lot depicted on or created by a resubdivision plat and each lot created by vacation of lot lines by recordation of a deed shall be subject to the public improvement requirements of this chapter and of article 18 of the zoning ordinance at the time that an application is filed for development of such lot including without limitation the payment of pro rata dedication of rightofway and installation of public improvements to serve the lot or lots shown on the resubdivision plat or created by vacation of lot lines by deed 3 municipal acquisitions other than rightofway the municipal acquisition or acceptance of real property in fee simple for governmental purposes other than rightofway improvements provided that no more than one additional lot is depicted on the plat each lot depicted on or created by a plat for municipal acquisitions other than rightofway including any residual parcel shall be subject to applicable requirements in this chapter for public improvements and pro rata payments upon development of such lot 4 municipal rightofway acquisitions the municipal acquisition or acceptance of real property in fee simple for purposes of rightofway improvements and extensions provided that no additional lots including any residual parcel are created or depicted on the acquisition plat for purposes of this definition the division of an existing lot or parcel by the rightofway acquisition shall not in itself constitute the creation of an additional lot 5 conservation divisions the division of property located wholly within an a1 agricultural district or c1 conservation district or combination thereof for purposes of preserving open space or environmentally sensitive lands including without limitation the creation restoration and preservation of wetlands provided that a all parcels created by the division of land meet minimum lot area requirements in the zoning ordinance  b the plat depicting the division of land contains a note stating that the division is for the sole purpose of creating one or more lots to be used for conservation purposes only and that no building permits or certificates of occupancy will be issued for such conservation areas other than as may be required for permitted passive recreational uses deemed incidental to and compatible with conservation objectives and amenities related to such approved passive recreational uses such as trails boardwalks and benches  c the planning director determines that adequate assurance of perpetual conservation has been given in the form of a permanent conservation or open space easement or by participation in a local state or federal program that will provide for the perpetual preservation of such lots including without limitation programs under which the property is to be dedicated to a local state or federal agency for conservation purposes evidence of perpetual conservation whether by deed of easement agreement deed of conveyance or other instrument shall be recorded in the clerks office of the circuit court of the city prior to or concurrent with the approval and recordation of the conservation division and shall contain provisions that perpetually restrict the use of the property for any purpose other than conservation and that prohibit all construction or land disturbance on the property other than amenities directly associated with approved passive recreational activities or landdisturbing activities required to establish restore or enhance wetlands  d no new or extended streets public easements or public facilities are required to serve the property as divided  and e the division of land does not result in more than one lot that will not be used for conservation purposes any such lot not used for conservation purposes shall conform with all requirements of this section and the citys zoning ordinance a division of land for conservation purposes shall exempt the lots encumbered with a recorded perpetual conservation instrument from lot frontage and lot width requirements in this chapter and in the citys zoning ordinance such lots shall also be exempt from the requirement for public improvements under articles ii of this chapter but shall meet all plat requirements applicable to agricultural divisions as set out in section 7022 the use restrictions whether in the form of a deed of easement agreement deed of conveyance or other acceptable instrument shall not be vacated released or amended in a manner that allows development or use of the property in whole or in part without the approval of city council and conformance with all requirements of the subdivision and zoning ordinance    2 commissions rules of procedure such comment should be limited to issues involving code compliance such as lot size and arrangement the width location and arrangement of streets utilities and other public facilities and other development criteria affecting the public health safety and welfare as set out in this the city zoning ordinance the city public facilities manual and other applicable policies and regulations of this city because the types of uses allowed on properties are controlled by the provisions of the city zoning ordinance public comment regarding the type of uses proposed for the subject property shall not be considered by the planning commission at the time of preliminary subdivision plan review b the subdivider or developer shall provide notice of the public hearing regarding the subject property by erecting on the subject property or at an appropriate adjoining location approved by the planning director one or more suitable signs facing and clearly visible from each public rightofway from which the property is visible other than interstates such sign shall be erected not less than 14 calendar days before the public hearing of which the sign gives notice and shall state the purpose of the public hearing regarding the subject property and the date time and place of the hearing it shall be the responsibility of the subdivider or developer to obtain the signs from the planning department the subdivider or developer shall continually maintain the signs until conclusion of the public hearing at which the matter is decided by the planning commission and shall remove and dispose of the signs within five days of the public hearing when the public hearing is continued on any one or more occasions the subdivider or developer shall be responsible for ensuring that the date on the signs is changed to reflect the next public hearing at which the preliminary subdivision plan is next to be considered the subdivider or developer shall be required to pay the sum of $2500 for the first sign required hereunder and $2000 for each additional sign where the planning commission finds that a sign has been inadequately posted or removed from a property it may at its discretion defer consideration of the plan involved  provided that however nothing contained herein shall be construed to invalidate any action by the planning commission concerning a preliminary subdivision plan because of the failure to post signs in accordance with this section so long as notice of the public hearing was advertised in a newspaper of general circulation at least once prior to each date on which review of the preliminary subdivision plan is scheduled to be heard by the planning commission any sign remaining on a property longer than five days after final action on the preliminary subdivision plan shall be deemed an illegal sign under the city zoning ordinance the city may remove and dispose of the illegal sign or take such other enforcement action deemed appropriate by the zoning administrator c a preliminary subdivision plan subject to public hearing before the planning commission shall not be considered to have been formally submitted for purposes of approval until a complete application has been filed in accordance with section 7024 and deemed complete by the director of planning or designee d the planning commission in its discretion planning commissions consideration of a preliminary subdivision plan to a subsequent meeting the planning commission shall be required to take final action on the application within 60 days of the meeting at which the applicant noted objection to the continuance in the event that the planning commission fails to approve or disapprove the preliminary subdivision plan within that period the applicant shall have such right to appeal as is provided for in the virginia if the preliminary subdivision plan requires additional review and approval by one or more state or federal agencies the planning commission shall be required to take action within 45 days of receiving all required approvals from those agencies 2 if the applicant requests a continuance or agrees to a continuance to a subsequent meeting of the planning commission that subsequent meeting shall be deemed the first formal meeting of the planning commission on such application for purposes of determining compliance with the time requirements set out in subsection 1 above e in cases where the planning commission has delegated approval authority of subdivision plans the planning director may adopt procedures  o006 12709  o052 51909  o050 8817 review of preliminary subdivision plans a departmental review a complete preliminary subdivision plan shall be reviewed by city staff as follows 1 an initial determination shall be made as to whether the preliminary subdivision plan is complete within 14 days of receipt by the planning department in the event the application is not complete the preliminary subdivision plan will be returned to the applicant with a description of the manner and areas in which the application is incomplete 2 once a preliminary subdivision plan is determined to be complete staff shall accept the plan for processing and review 3 each plan shall be reviewed and recommended for approval or denial b administrative review by planning director 1 first submittal for those preliminary subdivision plans for which the director of planning is the approval authority as designated by the planning commission the director shall approve or disapprove the preliminary subdivision plan within 60 days of the acceptance of a complete application unless the applicant agrees to an extension of this time period if a plan must be reviewed by a state agency or other public authority approval or denial shall occur within 35 days from the date of receipt of any agency response or the date that a response was due the preliminary subdivision plan shall be reviewed in accordance with the standards setout in subsection d in the case of approval of a preliminary subdivision plan the director of planning may impose conditions as deemed necessary to ensure full compliance with city ordinances regulations and policies and to protect the public health safety and welfare provided that such conditions do not exceed the needs generated by or the requirements of the proposed development property in case of disapproval the director of planning shall specify the reasons for the disapproval in writing citing applicable ordinances regulations or policies and shall generally identify the modifications that will permit approval of the plan all decisions of the director of planning shall be final unless the applicant files an appeal with the planning commission within 30 calendar days of the determination appealed from on forms approved by the city 2 resubmittal a a construction plan or other plan that does not involve commercial b1 b2 b5 mxdu or o&i or industrial zoning classifications shall be reviewed as a first submittal b a plan involving commercial b1 b2 b5 mxdu or o&i or industrial zoning classifications that is not considered a construction plan shall be approved or denied within 45 days after the resubmitted plan has been accepted as complete otherwise the resubmitted plan shall be deemed approved unless the plan would violate local state or federal law regulations mandatory department of transportation engineering and safety requirements and other mandatory engineering and safety requirements review of a resubmittal shall be limited to the deficiencies identified as the reasons for denial of the previous plan except for features corrections or changes not contained in the previous plan c review by planning commission for those preliminary subdivision plans for which the planning commission is the approval authority staff shall make its final recommendations for consideration by the planning commission no later than 45 days by the planning commission at the commissions next regularly scheduled subdivision plan review meeting the planning commission shall approve or disapprove the preliminary subdivision plan within the time periods set out in subsection 7023d d standards of review the planning commission or the director of planning when designated as the approval authority shall review each preliminary subdivision plan on the basis of the following factors 1 the completeness of the plan 2 compliance with the applicable provisions of this the city zoning ordinance the city public facilities manual and all other regulations and policies applicable to the site 3 the capacity of the plan in its proposed design to function in a manner that is compatible with adjoining properties and streets and conducive to the public health safety and welfare assessment of such compatibility shall include the following factors a the adequacy of the number of access points to adjoining streets and the relationship of such access points to access points from neighboring developments and properties b the number and nature of street connections to adjoining properties and the impact of such connections on the traffic flow onto and resulting safety of neighboring properties c the availability of continuous and unobstructed access for emergency vehicles d the capacity of the plan to provide sufficient drainage stormwater management and flood control to meet federal state and local requirements e the adequacy of landscaping and other buffering features to ensure compatibility with adjoining properties in accordance with article 19 of the city zoning ordinance f the adequacy of water and sewer facilities to serve the site g the adequacy of the plan in meeting all requirements imposed by article x of chapter 26 of this the cbpa specifications manual for properties located wholly or partially within the cbpa district 4 the capacity of the plan in its proposed design to ensure the safety and convenience of persons using and accessing the site including the adequacy of the design to provide for the smooth flow of traffic onsite and minimalization of conflicts with pedestrian traffic 5 the capacity of the plan to address adverse environmental conditions of the property in cases of subdivisions that involve land disturbance for residential assembly day care group home recreation school library or similar uses where exposure to contaminated soil or water would pose a threat to the public health safety and welfare including without limitation remediation and disclosure of soil and water contaminants presence of methane and gas and former or existing landfills on or in the vicinity of the property as used herein vicinity shall include parcels adjacent to the landfill site parcels separated from the landfill site by only a street or water body and parcels located downgradient of the landfill site all remediation and disclosure shall conform with the requirement of section 132600 of the zoning ordinance e approval by planning commission the planning commission shall grant approval of a preliminary subdivision plan which meets all applicable requirements of this the city preservation of natural features and amenities a in general 1 existing natural features which would add value to development or to the city as a whole such as trees watercourses historic spots and similar irreplaceable and beneficial assets shall be protected wherever practical in the design of the development special consideration should be given to specimen and historic trees and specimen vegetation 2 this section shall apply to apartment and townhouse developments and office and commercial developments adjacent to established singlefamily residential developments bona fide farming forestry projects and commercial tree businesses are exempt from the regulations contained in this section b definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning historic tree means any tree which has been specifically designated by the city council to have been closely associated with an historical event place or age person knowledgeable means a person because of education and training having the skills necessary to determine types and characteristics of trees including planting and protection methods such person shall meet the experience criteria required for the virginia nurserymen certification specimen trees and shrubs means any woody plant which due to circumference height or location is deemed to be an unusual example of its species such woody plants deemed to be specimens will generally qualify as a record or champion tree under the criteria of the virginia forestry association and will be certified as such or have certification pending a specimen tree or shrub may also qualify as such on the basis of location being any woody plant at the extremity of its natural range as defined by the old dominion university botany department tree means any selfsupporting woody plant growing upon the earth which usually produces one main trunk measuring no less than four inches in diameter at 4 feet from the ground with a minimum overall height of 15 feet and which produces a more or less distinct and elevated head with many branches c site analysis in conjunction with the preparation of a preliminary or final plat the developerowner shall cause to be made by a person knowledgeable a site analysis showing all of the natural features and amenities present on the property this analysis and resulting preliminary plat shall consider the following 1 the adaptability and compatibility of existing trees with proposed development including a consideration that additional fill material for construction activities will be necessary 2 the presence of specimen andor historic trees and shrubs 3 the presence of rare or endangered vegetation which may be relocated by transplanting 4 the adequacy of proposed protection measures 5 the numbers health and vigor of trees located in areas designated for retention 6 the proposed removal of trees shall be based on the fact that such trees are damaged or diseased that their presence would unduly restrict the use or enjoyment of the property that such trees are too close to proposed building or utilities or would unduly impede drainage 7 alternative landscaping measures which would protect and preserve such amenities d review of plats information derived from subsection c of this section shall form the basis for such conservation replanting and landscaping plans for the project as required by the planning commission in its review of the developerowners preliminary and final plats the planning commission may grant variances or other modifications from the requirements of this section provided that the purpose of same is preserved e additional plat requirements 1 the total number of trees to be retained or planted by the developerowner shall at a minimum be equal to one per unit for townhouse developments and one per four units for apartment projects healthy natural trees retained shall be considered to be two planted trees at such time as 50 percent of the development has been constructed at least 30 percent of the items shown on the approved landscaping plan shall have been completed the final ten percent of such development shall not be occupied until the total landscaping plan has been completed 2 the side andor rear yards of business and office and institutional zoned areas as prescribed by section 53 of the city zoning ordinance which abut residentially zoned property shall be utilized as a planted buffer including fencing as well as natural or planted growth 3 replanted trees shall be at least two inches in caliper f enforcement 1 this section shall be enforced by the director of the department of planning or designee 2 after approval of a final plat a landscaping permit shall be obtained by the developerowner from the department of planning a fee as specified in section 70191 must be paid for the permit upon final completion of required landscaping the developerowner shall coordinate a field inspection by a representative of the department of planning to determine compliance with the approved plat 1 under review and all public comments regarding the extension should be directed to the department of planning the sign shall be posted for at least 30 days before approval of the preliminary subdivision plan on the applicants property in a manner that is visible from the culdesac and not more that ten feet beyond the edge of the pavement c in cases where a stub street is proposed if the same exceeds the depth of one lot a temporary turnaround shall be provided all stub streets with a temporary turnaround shall have a sign at the streets terminus stating the temporary nature of such turnaround d blocks in general shall not be longer than 1400 feet between intersections unless warranted by some unusual condition e no plat shall be approved for recordation which reserves a narrow strip of land around or along any or all sides of the property which is commonly known as a spite wall or strip f in general the centerlines of all intersecting streets shall meet at a common point and shall intersect one another as near to a right angle as is practicable g all maps or plats of a subdivision presented for approval or recordation vacating plats heretofore recorded shall show the plat book and page number of the plat being vacated h no subdivision shall be approved unless provided with a street having a minimum dedication of 50 feet connecting the subdivision with an existing designed as to have no appreciable detrimental effect upon the functioning of the existing system of water sewerage and drainage facilities and improvements in the area a subdivider shall provide all those improvements necessary to ensure that the water sewerage and drainage demands created by the subdivision or development are properly serviced b where the city has established a water and sewer improvement andor a drainage improvement plan for an area having related and common water and sewer andor drainage conditions and improvements are constructed to serve the demands generated by subdivisions and developments within that area each subdivider or developer whose project will be served by such improvements may be required as a condition of subdivision or development approval to pay its pro rata share of the cost of providing such improvement such share shall be based upon the impact which a subdivision or development has upon the rate of flow of water sewerage or drainage improvements with such impact expressed as a percentage of the total rate of flow such improvements are intended to service that percentage shall then be applied to the total cost of designing and installing such improvements to determine the value of the pro rata share required c once an improvement plan has been established for an area approval of all subdivisions and developments within the area shall be subject to the compatibility of the subdivisions or developments with such plan including construction and utilization of water sewer and drainage improvements by such subdivisions or developments in accordance with the terms of the plan d where a subdivider or developer constructs such improvements designed to service other subdivisions or developments as provided for in an established water sewer or drainage improvement plan and the cost of constructing such improvements exceeds the value of the subdividers or developers pro rata obligations as determined by the city pursuant to this section any subsequent subdivider or developer utilizing such improvements in accordance with such plan shall reimburse the subdivider or developer constructing such improvements for the cost of such construction in accordance with the degree to which such subdivider or developer utilizes such improvements as determined by the city however a subdivider or developer constructing such improvements may transfer to the city its right to such reimbursement in regard to water and sewer improvements in exchange for being given entitlement to the connection fees imposed upon the lots within its subdivision or development pursuant to section 7886 such entitlement shall not exceed the value of the pro rata payment to which such subdivider or developer would otherwise be entitled as determined by the city    2     offsite road improvements  voluntary funding and reimbursements if a subdivider or developer makes an advance of payments for or construction of reasonable make available for such purpose from time to time for the cost of such advance together with interest which shall be excludable from gross income for federal income tax purposes at a rate equal to the rate of interest on bonds most recently issued by the city council on the following terms and conditions 1 the city council shall determine or confirm that the road improvements were substantially generated and reasonably required by the construction or improvement of the subdivision or development and shall determine or confirm the cost thereof on the basis of a study or studies conducted by qualified traffic engineers and approved and accepted by the subdivider or developer 2 the city council shall prepare or cause to be prepared a report accepted and approved by the subdivider or developer indicating the governmental services required to be furnished to the subdivision or development and an estimate of the annual cost thereof for the period during which the reimbursement is to be made to the subdivider or developer 3 the city council may make annual reimbursements to the subdivider or developer from funds made available for such purpose from time to time including but not limited to real estate taxes assessed and collected against the land and improvements on the property included in the subdivision or developments in amounts equal to the amount by which such real utilized 1 municipal owned and operated source this source shall be considered an extension of the citys distribution system and shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the citys published policies standards and criteria 2 central subdivision supply this source to be approved by the health department consists of a local central water supply and a network of distribution lines and appurtenances which shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the citys published policies standards and criteria this requirement shall provide for the orderly abandonment of the private central water supply and the connection of the distribution lines to the citys system when such system becomes available 3 individual water supply this type of system shall consist of individual wells serving one lot or parcel of land after determining that neither system described in subsections a1 and a2 of this section is available the local health department shall be the approval agent for the location of the well b the following methods of sewage disposal may be utilized 1 municipal owned and operated collection system this system shall be considered as an extension of the citys sanitary sewer system and shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the citys published policies standards and criteria 2 central subdivision disposal this system shall consist of a local central disposal facility and a network of sewer collection lines and appurtenances which shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the citys published policies standards and criteria this requirement shall include indemnification of the city for system failures and deficiencies and shall further provide for the orderly abandonment of the central disposal facility and the connection of the collection system to the citys system when such system becomes available no approval shall be given for a new central disposal system including without limitation private sewage package plants unless or until a conditional use permit is granted by city council as required by the city zoning ordinance 3 individual disposal method this system shall consist of individual septic tanks serving one lot or parcel of land after determining that neither system described in subsections b1 and b2 of this section is available the use of individual septic tanks shall be approved by the local health department or other appropriate regulatory authority if in compliance with the state health department and environmental regulations no approval shall be given for newly installed septic tanks that are dependent on one or more offsite regional drainfields designed to serve more than one residential dwelling unit or more than one nonresidential parcel unless and until a conditional use permit is granted by city council as required by the city zoning ordinance    2  o148 112205  o136 102108 predesign conferences predesign conferences with the public utilities basis for the development design as shown on the diagrammatic sketch plan b review the existing resources and site analysis map shall be submitted prior or the preapplication meeting required in section 70202 above the city shall review the existing resources and site analysis map to assess its accuracy conformance with city ordinances and the likely impact of the proposed cluster development on the natural and cultural resources on the property c content the existing resources and site analysis map shall conform with the following criteria 1 the map shall generally be prepared at a scale of one inch   100 feet or one inch   200 feet whichever would fit best on a single standard size sheet 24 inches by 36 inches 2 a vertical aerial photograph enlarged to a scale not less detailed than one inch   400 feet with the site boundaries clearly marked 3 topography the contour lines of which shall generally be at twofoot intervals determined by photogrammetry although tenfoot intervals are permissible beyond the parcel boundaries interpolated from usgs published maps topography shall be delineated by a professional land surveyor or professional engineer from an actual field survey of the site or from stereoscopic aerial photography and shall be coordinated with official usgs benchmarks 4 the location and delineation of ponds streams ditches drains and natural drainage swales as well as 100year floodplains tidal wetlands and nontidal wetlands 5 vegetative cover on the property including cultivated land permanent grassland meadow pasture old field hedgerow woodlands wetlands trees with a caliper in excess of 15 inches and the actual canopy line of existing trees and woodlands vegetative types shall be described by plant community relative age and condition 6 soil series types and phases as mapped by the us department of agriculture natural resources conservation service in the published soil survey for the city and accompanying data published for each soil type relating to its suitability for construction and where no public sewer is available for suitability for subsurface septic facilities 7 ridge lines and watershed boundaries 8 a viewshed analysis showing the location and extent of views into the property from public roads and from public parks public forests and state game lands 9 all existing manmade features including but not limited to streets driveways farm roads woods roads buildings structures foundations walls wells drainage fields public utilities fire hydrants and storm and sanitary sewers 10 locations of all historically significant sites or structures on the tract including but not limited to historic homes earthworks and graves 11 locations of trails that have been in public use eg pedestrian equestrian and bicycle trails 12 all easements and other encumbrances of property that are of record with the clerk of the circuit court 13 total acreage of the tract plus adjusted tract acreage with detailed supporting calculations 14 the boundaries of overlay districts utility service areas and utility franchise areas 15 conditions of land within 500 feet of the property as may be described on the basis of existing published data available from governmental agencies and aerial photographs o080 51804 site inspection conference a site inspection after preparing the existing resources and site analysis map the and to provide an informal opportunity to discuss site design concepts including the general layout of designated conservation land and potential locations for proposed buildings and street alignments
